description.narrative: To support Vulnerability ,risk Assessment and adaptation planning to help small holder farmers and partners integrate disaster riskreduction and climate change adaptation in farming systems.Climate change, through its impact on climate extremes and other weatherand climate events, is expected to increase disaster risk in many parts of the country. Weather related hazards will negatively impact the productive assets and coping capacities of vulnerable poor communities, threatening development gains. Closer integration between disaster risk management (DRM) and climate change adaptation is needed to mitigate the impact of these changes, with effectiveDRR in the short term facilitating adaptation of climate change in the long term. Oxfam resilience building in partnership with theInternational Institute of Rural Reconstruction (IIRR) seeks to strengthen local and national capacities for preparedness, adaptation and effective response through Risk and vulnerability capacity building of DDMCS and Civil society, facilitating Risk and Vulnerability assessment, Mapping and risk reduction and adaptation planning as well as contingency planning.

participating-org.narrative: INTERNATIONAL INST. OF RURAL RECONS IIRR

The International Institute of Rural Reconstruction (IIRR) was registered in 1960 in the Delaware state of USA. Before then, it operated as the rural reconstruction movement, founded by Dr. James Yen in early 1920#s. It started as an Education Movement to spread literacy in rural China. Gradually, as the movement spread to the Philippines, Taiwan and other countries in Asia and Africa, IIRR began to tackle other root causes of poverty other than illiteracy namely health, civic inertia and hunger. As a result, IIRR started implementing health, governance and food security programs. In the recent years, climate change impact on food security became a reality and thus IIRR pioneered the Community-managed Disaster risk reduction (CMDRR) approach that is mainstreamed within its food security programs. All IIRR programs adopt rights based and inclusive approach that is pro poor.
IIRR headquarters are in the Philippines which also serves as the regional centre for Asia with other country programs in Cambodia, Philippines and Myanmar. In Africa,IIRR regional centre is in Nairobi, Kenya and other IIRR country programs include Uganda, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Zimbabwe and Kenya. IIRR Uganda was registered in Uganda in 2006 under the NGO registration regulations. IIRR is a not for profit organization that seeks to overcome poverty through innovation and community empowerment. Our flagship programs as per our 2016-2020 Strategy are Foodsecurity and Livelihood Resilience (FSLR) and Education in marginalized communities and pastoralist areas. The FSLR program integrates Disaster Risk Response and Climate Change. Building local governance capacities for rural development is mainstreamed in all theprograms. Through the Applied Learning program, we provide demandled capacity building to development actors. This includes advertised and customized courses, documentation and publication support services using the writeshop process and technical assistance. More information about IIRR is available on our website www.iirr.org
IIRR embraces the principle of inclusion in all its dimensions, including gender, ethnic, cultural, racial, religious, sexual orientation, abilities or disabilities, and health. IIRR upholds diversity as key for practical and strategic approach to global development challenges. In this regard, IIRR has in place a gender policy to articulate its position on gender equity and to identify practical ways in which this can be applied at institutional, program/project and partnership levels. We also have a HIV/AIDS workplace policy. We have active programs in Gender and HIV/AIDS with a focal person to hold the organization and staff accountable. With respect to recruitment, IIRR has in place mechanisms to ensure fair recruitment and placement of staff to ensure gender, ethnic and minority representation. This ensures that in all our work, we remain balanced and sensitive to the needs of all groups. For example, 70% of the IIRR Country management team are women. In the field programming, IIRR has adopted the Gender Action Learning Systems (GALS) methodology to integrate and strengthen gender in decision making in the agricultural value chain programs we implement.
